text:
Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty"? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

In my opinion,

Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty"? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

In my opinion, pads and tampons are a necessity in just the same way as toilet paper, soap, and so on. In fact, not providing them is arguably a case of sex discrimination, since all other essentials are supplied. In addition, for school students, puberty is a time when they are still adjusting to needing these supplies, and they may not be prepared. School students also have to rely on adults for at least most of their money, since they cannot be employed if they are under the employment age, and if they are old enough to work they cannot work more than 20 hours per week.

School students also have to rely on adults for at least most of their money, since they cannot be employed if they are under the employment age, and if they are old enough to work they cannot work more than 20 hours per week. 

In addition, it is not just a matter of convenience.

Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty"? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

In my opinion, pads and tampons are a necessity in just the same way as toilet paper, soap, and so on. In fact, not providing them is arguably a case of sex discrimination, since all other essentials are supplied. In addition, for school students, puberty is a time when they are still adjusting to needing these supplies, and they may not be prepared. School students also have to rely on adults for at least most of their money, since they cannot be employed if they are under the employment age, and if they are old enough to work they cannot work more than 20 hours per week. 

In addition, it is not just a matter of convenience. This is a health issue, because the ability to have clean sanitary supplies can help to prevent infections. Since schools are invested in helping students have basic good health in other ways, such as providing a nurse's office, it makes sense to provide a cleanliness necessity just as they supply toilet paper.

How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

In fact, not providing them is arguably a case of sex discrimination, since all other essentials are supplied. In addition, for school students, puberty is a time when they are still adjusting to needing these supplies, and they may not be prepared. School students also have to rely on adults for at least most of their money, since they cannot be employed if they are under the employment age, and if they are old enough to work they cannot work more than 20 hours per week. 

In addition, it is not just a matter of convenience. This is a health issue, because the ability to have clean sanitary supplies can help to prevent infections. Since schools are invested in helping students have basic good health in other ways, such as providing a nurse's office, it makes sense to provide a cleanliness necessity just as they supply toilet paper. 

The main way that pads and tampons are different is that only one group needs them. But this does not argue against providing the supplies. Since it is a biological basic necessity, it is not a matter of choice.

Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty"? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

In my opinion, pads and tampons are a necessity in just the same way as toilet paper, soap, and so on. In fact, not providing them is arguably a case of sex discrimination, since all other essentials are supplied. In addition, for school students, puberty is a time when they are still adjusting to needing these supplies, and they may not be prepared. School students also have to rely on adults for at least most of their money, since they cannot be employed if they are under the employment age, and if they are old enough to work they cannot work more than 20 hours per week. 

In addition, it is not just a matter of convenience. This is a health issue, because the ability to have clean sanitary supplies can help to prevent infections. Since schools are invested in helping students have basic good health in other ways, such as providing a nurse's office, it makes sense to provide a cleanliness necessity just as they supply toilet paper.

Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty"? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

In my opinion, pads and tampons are a necessity in just the same way as toilet paper, soap, and so on. In fact, not providing them is arguably a case of sex discrimination, since all other essentials are supplied. In addition, for school students, puberty is a time when they are still adjusting to needing these supplies, and they may not be prepared. School students also have to rely on adults for at least most of their money, since they cannot be employed if they are under the employment age, and if they are old enough to work they cannot work more than 20 hours per week. 

In addition, it is not just a matter of convenience. This is a health issue, because the ability to have clean sanitary supplies can help to prevent infections. Since schools are invested in helping students have basic good health in other ways, such as providing a nurse's office, it makes sense to provide a cleanliness necessity just as they supply toilet paper. 

The main way that pads and tampons are different is that only one group needs them. But this does not argue against providing the supplies. Since it is a biological basic necessity, it is not a matter of choice. The same is true for toilet paper, soap, and other products. This really means that not providing these supplies is ignoring a group's basic needs while needs that apply to all students are supplied. It also suggests that those making these types of decisions were not thinking about it and not consulting with those who use the bathrooms. 

To suggest that money is an issue here is to miss the point, because if the school can afford to supply other basic necessities such as indigestion medicine, toilet paper, soap, hand dryers, and tylenol, then pads and tampons fall into the same category and should be paid for from the same budget.

Should Schools Provide Free Pads and Tampons?

Have you ever experienced period shaming, or “period poverty"? Should schools step in to help? Should schools be required to provide free pads and tampons to students? How are pads and tampons similar to toilet paper, soap, Band-Aids and other products that are already provided in schools? How are they different?

---

In my opinion, pads and tampons are a necessity in just the same way as toilet paper, soap, and so on. In fact, not providing them is arguably a case of sex discrimination, since all other essentials are supplied. In addition, for school students, puberty is a time when they are still adjusting to needing these supplies, and they may not be prepared. The supplies need to be available conveniently. 

In addition, it is not just a matter of convenience. This is a health issue, because the ability to have clean sanitary supplies can help to prevent infections. Since schools are invested in helping students have basic good health in other ways, such as providing a nurse's office, it makes sense to provide a cleanliness necessity just as they supply toilet paper. 

The main way that pads and tampons are different is that only one group needs them. But this does not argue against providing the supplies. Since it is a biological basic necessity, it is not a matter of choice. The same is true for toilet paper, soap, and other products. This really means that not providing these supplies is ignoring a group's basic needs while needs that apply to all students are supplied. It also suggests that those making these types of decisions were not thinking about it and not consulting with those who use the bathrooms. 

To suggest that money is an issue here is to miss the point, because if the school can afford to supply other basic necessities such as indigestion medicine, toilet paper, soap, hand dryers, and tylenol, then pads and tampons fall into the same category and should be paid for from the same budget. School students also have to rely on adults for at least most of their money, since they cannot be employed if they are under the employment age, and if they are old enough to work they cannot work more than 20 hours per week. Many students' families cannot afford everything they need and rely on the school to meet them partway by providing basic needs during the school day. In conclusion, yes, school should supply sanitary products for students.
